Title: Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Overview Creating a Website Collector Style and Behavior Settings Collector Options Embed Tips Help Sending Surveys More Ways to Send Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website SurveyMonkey Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website Overview Creating a Website Collector Style and Behavior Settings Collector Options Embed Tips Overview Use a website collector to embed a survey or a button that opens a survey on your website, or popup a survey or invitation. To add one, you only need a basic understanding of HTML and access to your website’s source code. We’ll give you an embed code you can copy and paste. You can embed a survey on multiple pages of your site, if you want. Website Collector Types Type Description Embedded survey Embed your survey on any page of your site so people can take it right there. Embedded button Beta feature : Embed a button on your website that launches your survey when selected. The button continues to display on your site even after someone took the survey. Popup invitation Show a survey invitation in a popup window that links people to your survey. The survey opens in a new browser tab. Popup survey Show your survey in a popup window when people visit a page, without needing to embed the survey in the page layout. Modal Windows Popup Invitations and Popup Surveys show in modal windows that float above your webpage. Modal windows don't require your site visitors to load a new page, and they aren't affected by popup blockers. Cookies We use cookies to stop popups or embedded surveys from reshowing if someone already answered, declined, or closed the survey. If someone clears their cookies, visits your site using a browser that blocks or disables cookies, or the website is opened in a new browser session, the collector can’t remember whether they’ve taken the survey or declined it, so the popup may appear again allowing additional responses. Closing Your Survey When you close your survey , it continues to display on your website, unless you remove the embed code from your site. Creating a Website Collector To create a Website collector: Go to the Collect Response section of your survey. Choose Embed on a site . If you already have a collector for your survey, select Website collector . Choose a website collector type . Scroll down to edit the the style and behavior settings, and adjust the collector options. View the preview to know what your survey will look like on your website. Click Copy Code to copy and paste the embed code onto a page in your site. When embedding a survey or button , paste the script into your HTML wherever you want the survey to appear on your page. When showing a Popup invitation or Popup survey , paste the script into your HTML immediately before your closing </body> tag. The code only needs to be added once. You don’t need to update the Embed code if you make changes to your survey or collector—your updates will display as soon as you refresh the page. Style and Behavior Settings The live survey preview updates as you customize your style and behavior settings for your survey. Settings vary by website type . Setting Description Width and Height Specify how many pixels wide or tall you want the survey to be. When using the Embedded survey type, turn on the Custom size toggle to access these settings. If you leave the toggle off, your survey will match the width of the HTML element containing your survey or form. SurveyMonkey branding You may see a toggle or checkbox which controls whether "powered by SurveyMonkey" displays on the bottom border of your survey. If you remove the SurveyMonkey branding, you may also want to remove SurveyMonkey branding from the survey itself. Border or Footer Edit the border color of the window or footer to help your invitation or survey stand out. Invitation or Survey headline Catch your visitor’s attention with a headline that’s no more than 2 lines. You can edit the text, but not the font, size, or color. Invitation message Explain the goal of the survey in 1 – 3 short sentences. You can edit the text, but not the font, size, or color. Primary button This Popup invitation button opens your survey. You can edit the button text, button color, and button text color. Secondary button This Popup invitation button closes the invitation window. You can edit the button text, button color, and button text color. Sample Rate Choose the percentage of visitors to see your Popup invitation or popup survey. Embed button The button embedded on your page that opens your window. You can edit the button label, color, and text color. Popup label This is the text introducing your popup survey. Behavior Choose whether to show the popup immediately, after a delay (measured in seconds), after the visitor scrolls a specific percentage down the page, or when they’re about to leave your page. Collector Options Update the collector options , which are called Settings on the Embedded button type, to customize the survey experience. Some collector options are limited on certain website collector types: Embedded surveys don't have a Survey end page option. Instant results aren't available on any website collector type. The Custom thank you includes SurveyMonkey branding at the end of an Embedded survey, even if you chose to Hide SurveyMonkey Branding . Embed Tips Please don’t edit the Embed code! The Embed code contains several lines of JavaScript and a unique ID that's tied to both your collector and your survey. You can paste the embed code on a single or multiple pages by pasting the embed code before the </body> tag. If you want all pages of your site to display the survey, button, or invitation, paste the embed code before the </header> tag. If you use templates to dynamically generate pages for your site (if you’re using Ruby, Python, PHP, ASP, or a similar technology), you can paste the Embed code snippet into its own file, then include it in your page layout. If you’re using wordpress.org, you need to be an administrator to add the code, or a super admin for multi-site wordpress.org networks. Website collectors aren’t compatible with wordpress.com. Title: Copying a Survey | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Copying a Survey | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey Help Managing & Sharing Surveys Organizing & Copying Copying a Survey SurveyMonkey Copying a Survey Copying a survey creates a duplicate version of the survey design in your account. This is helpful so you don't have to start from scratch or make edits to past surveys you've sent that already have recorded responses. How to Make a Copy To copy a survey: From Home , find the survey you want to make a copy of. Click the three dots ( ... ) to the right of the survey and select Make a copy . The copied survey will open to the Design Survey tab. Click the survey title to edit the survey title and nickname. Edit the survey. You can edit the copied version however you'd like without affecting the original survey or its responses. Additional Info When making a copy of a survey, keep this info in mind: Themes, logos, logic, and other survey design settings carry over to the copied version of the survey. With a free plan, you can't copy surveys with more than 10 questions. You can copy surveys shared with you . You need to create a new collector to send your survey. Nothing is copied from the Collect Responses tab or Analyze Results tab, including responses, collectors, rules, shared data pages, or dashboards. Title: Making Responses Anonymous | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Making Responses Anonymous | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Tips for Anonymous Surveys Web Links Email Invitations Other Collector Types Respondent Authentication Collectors Created by Integrations Help Sending Surveys Tracking & Anonymity Making Responses Anonymous SurveyMonkey Making Responses Anonymous Tips for Anonymous Surveys Web Links Email Invitations Other Collector Types Respondent Authentication Collectors Created by Integrations The Anonymous Responses collector option lets you choose whether or not to track and store identifiable respondent information in survey results. SurveyMonkey records respondent IP addresses in backend logs and deletes them after 13 months. Tips for Anonymous Surveys If you’re using multiple collectors, you need to turn on Anonymous Responses in each collector. If you want your survey to be anonymous, don’t include identifiable questions in your survey design and don’t use identifiable custom data or custom variables when sending your survey. If you have an Enterprise plan , Primary Admins can choose a default Anonymous Responses setting for their entire team. If you need your survey responses to be anonymous, turn on the Anonymous Responses setting before you send your survey. While you can edit anonymous responses after sending the survey, it’s not possible to make existing responses anonymous. Changing the setting only applies to new responses. Web Links Web Links record the IP addresses of respondents by default. To turn on Anonymous Responses: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the collector. Click Anonymous Responses and choose On . Email Invitations Email Invitations are designed to help you track respondents, so your survey results will include the email address and IP address of each respondent by default. Additionally, the first name, last name, and custom data about your contacts is tracked, if you included this information in the collector. To turn on Anonymous Responses: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the collector. Go to the collector options . If you've already sent an invitation, go to the Options tab. When sending your first invitation message in the collector, you'll choose collector options after composing your message. Click Anonymous Responses . Choose to exclude all respondent information to exclude first name, last name, email address, IP address, and custom data from your results. Or choose only exclude personal information to exclude first name, last name, email address, and IP address from your results. TIP! Even if Anonymous Responses is turned on, you can still track email invitations . This info is tied to the email invitation, not to survey results. Other Collector Types By default, most collectors record the IP addresses of respondents in survey results. You can turn on Anonymous Responses to prevent IP tracking. To turn on Anonymous Responses: Go to the collector options for your collector Turn on Make Anonymous or turn off Save IP Address in Results? Respondent Authentication When Respondent Authentication is turned on, the survey is never anonymous because the survey taker’s SSO profile information is tracked. Collectors Created by Integrations Some integrations automatically create collectors in SurveyMonkey, like the Microsoft Teams integration . Whether a survey is anonymous or not is dependent on the integration's settings rather than the Anonymous Responses collector option. Title: Progress Bar | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Progress Bar | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Settings Help Creating Surveys Themes & Format Options Progress Bar SurveyMonkey Progress Bar Settings Progress bars let people to see how much of the survey they've finished, and how much they still need to complete. To turn the progress bar on or off: Click the Design Survey tab. In the left sidebar, click OPTIONS . Click Progress Bar . Toggle Show Progress Bar on or off. Skip Logic If you're using any logic in your survey, hide the progress bar. The progress bar doesn't recalculate if people are skipped past certain questions or pages, so it might confuse people taking your survey. Settings Setting Description Position Display the progress bar at the top or bottom of the page. Format Display the number of pages that have been completed so far, or the percentage of pages that have been completed so far. Exceptions When using the One Question at a Time format, the progress bar can only display how many questions (out of the total) the respondent has answered, rather than how many pages or the percentage they've completed. When Skip logic is applied, the progress bar displays the percentage of pages completed. However, if both One Question at a Time and Skip logic are applied, the progress bar only displays how many questions the respondent answered so far. To display the percentage format, switch the survey format to Classic. Title: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Help Analyzing Results Understanding Your Results Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI SurveyMonkey Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Analyze with AI helps you find key insights and trends in your survey data by responding to your questions with charts and insight summaries. With Analyze with AI, you can: Uncover insights based on responses, timeframes, and more in seconds Ask for comparisons, or information about specific segments Visualize data points based on your results Export and share any charts that Analyze with AI creates for you How it works: Analyze with AI helps you segment, summarize, and visualize your survey responses to quickly gather insights. It doesn’t modify anything in your survey, such as applying filters to responses on the page, editing charts, or building dashboards. It draws insights from all of your results, regardless of any filters you’ve applied. What it can analyze: Analyze with AI can analyze these question types and data: Multiple Choice Checkbox Dropdown NPS Star Rating Matrix/Rating Scale Ranking Matrix of Dropdown Menus Comment Box (if responses are tagged) Single Text Box (if responses are tagged) Basic demographic information (for surveys sent via SurveyMonkey Audience ) How to analyze Comment Box and Single Text Box: Analyze with AI can only analyze open-ended text responses if they’re tagged. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can generate sentiments and themes for deeper insights into open-ended responses. You’ll also see any tags or themes that Analyze with AI created on the Question Summaries page. Analyze with AI also supports existing tags that you’ve created via Sentiment Analysis, Thematic Analysis, rule-based tagging , or manual tagging . Survey Requirements Analyze with AI is available for surveys that meet these requirements: The survey language is in English Your survey has between 1 and 10,000 responses Limitations Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about your account or offer product support. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about logic, advanced branching, or piping that have been applied to your survey. The feature may not be able to answer questions about complex custom variables or custom data added to your collectors. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about “Other” textbox responses from Multiple Choice, Checkboxes, and Star Rating Scale question types. Certain survey use cases are not permitted—for details, please see SurveyMonkey's Acceptable Uses Policy , as well as additional third party provider usage policies , and acceptable use and conduct policies Feature Availability and Settings Analyze with AI is only available to some customers in supported regions. The way you access this feature depends on your plan: Individual plans : If Analyze with AI is available for your plan, you can access it at any time. Teams and Enterprise plans : Your Primary Admin determines whether your team can access Analyze with AI . For details on the terms that apply to the use of this feature, please see our Self-Serve AI Service-Specific Terms and SurveyMonkey Enterprise Service-Specific Terms . HIPAA and Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection : Analyze with AI isn’t available to HIPAA-enabled accounts, or those with the Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection feature enabled. Additionally, based on your plan type, Analyze with AI may set limitations on the number of questions available per survey. Advantage Premier Enterprise Question Limits per User 20 questions per survey 50 per survey Unlimited per survey Analyze with AI is also subject to fair use of the feature, so your account may be temporarily disabled if we notice abnormal activity. How Your Data is Processed Analyze with AI uses Azure Open AI service or Open AI to generate insights about your survey. Your content isn’t used to train these third party providers’ models. Learn more about how this feature processes your data . Don’t include sensitive or personal information in your questions – you are responsible for the information you enter in Analyze with AI. Analyze with AI’s answers may have limitations based on the survey data or how you phrased your questions. Review the results carefully. Use of this feature is subject to additional terms, as described in our Service-Specific Terms . Using Analyze with AI To use Analyze with AI: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. To include open-text questions in your analysis, make sure to tag text responses. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can tag your responses for you. You can also use rule-based tagging or manual tagging . Select Analyze with AI in the top right corner of the Question Summaries page. If you don’t see the Analyze with AI option, the feature isn’t available for your survey or account. Accept the terms and conditions. Type your question, or select View suggestions and select a suggested question. Select Send to ask your question. Understanding and Rating Answers Analyze with AI provides a text explanation in each answer. Some answers include a chart or table. Hover over the info icon below the chart to learn how Analyze with AI got this result. You can also see the survey questions that Analyze with AI used for its answer. You can rate the answer to let us know if it was helpful or accurate. Select the thumbs up or thumbs down button to rate the answer. You can also leave a comment about your negative rating or submit your feedback via the feedback form. Your ratings help us improve Analyze with AI and provide more relevant answers in the future. Asking Useful Questions Here are a few tips to improve the answers you get from Analyze with AI. Expand | Collapse Use the terms “responses” and “respondents” carefully. Use respondents to ask about the total number of individuals. Use responses If you want the number of votes or choices. Use terms and concepts from your survey. This helps Analyze with AI understand what data to find and analyze for you. For example, if your survey is about a specific product or industry, ask questions that include the product or industry in your survey. Be specific. Clearly define what specific aspect of the data you are inquiring about. Example : Don’t ask what the “best product” is. Instead, you can ask, “Which product has the highest satisfaction level?" Avoid general questions. Instead, target specific questions, metrics, or trends. Example : If you’re asking about NPS scores, don’t ask, “How much positive feedback did we get?” Instead, ask about the percentage of promoters. Use clear and direct language. Avoid jargon or overly complex terms unless they are directly relevant to your survey. Quantify when possible. Ask for numbers or percentages to get more specific results. Example : "What percentage of respondents were very satisfied with the product quality?" Ask for comparative analysis If you’re interested in trends, comparisons, or changes, specify the exact parameters you want compared. Example: "Compare the satisfaction levels between different age groups." Focus on actionable insights. Ask for actionable insights or recommendations. Example: "Based on the survey responses, what areas should we focus on to improve customer satisfaction?" Consider data breakdown Specify if you need a breakdown of responses by certain demographics or categories. Example: "What are the satisfaction levels by geographic region?" Seek clarifications on anomalies If you notice any unusual patterns or outliers in your data, ask for clarifications or deeper analysis. Example: "Why might there be a higher dissatisfaction rate among customers aged 18-24?" Ask a different question when you get the wrong result. If Analyze with AI doesn’t answer your question with the right information, ask again in a different way. Use the thumbs up and thumbs down to rate the responses so we can improve Analyze with AI. Title: Creating a Web Link for Your Survey | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Creating a Web Link for Your Survey | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Video Overview Creating a Web Link Collector Options Tracking Survey Takers Create a Copy of a Web Link Help Sending Surveys Sharing a Link to a Survey Creating a Web Link for Your Survey SurveyMonkey Creating a Web Link for Your Survey Video Overview Creating a Web Link Collector Options Tracking Survey Takers Create a Copy of a Web Link The Web link collector lets you share a URL or QR code linking to your survey. You can send or post your survey anywhere you want—like on social media, in an email (using your own email client), or print it on a newsletter. By default, your survey URL will look something like this, with a string of letters and numbers at the end: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/P58B9BX TIP! Download a QR code for your survey to print on pamphlets, flyers, or posters. Video Overview Creating a Web Link To create a Web Link: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Choose Send surveys your way and then Share a survey link . If you already have a collector created and don't see that option, click Add New Collector and select Web link collector . Choose your collector options . (Optional) Click Customize to use a custom URL ending or change the domain . (Optional) Edit the nickname of the collector by clicking the pencil icon—this nickname does not show to survey takers. Copy the survey link and paste it wherever you'd like. The link works as long as the collector is open —Web link collectors are open by default. Beta Experienc e: Some customers may see a Web link automatically created when they initially go to the Collect Responses section. To create a web link: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. A URL is automatically created for you under Share a link. If you already created another collector or don't see a Web link URL ready for you to use, you can click Share a link to create a new Web link. Choose your collector options . (Optional) Click Link settings to: Use a custom URL ending Change the domain Edit the nickname of the collector by clicking the pencil icon—this nickname does not show to respondents, Under Share a link , click Copy and paste it wherever you'd like. The link works as long as the collector is open —Web link collectors are open by default. Web Links are Public Links Your Web link collector URL is a public link, meaning that anyone who has it will be able to access your survey and complete it. Web crawlers can also access public links, but they won't index your survey on a search engine. Tip! If you wish to use a Web link collector but do not want the link to be public, consider password-protecting your survey . Collector Options It isn't possible to transfer or reuse a SurveyMonkey generated URL ending. Depending on your plan, you can create a Custom URL Ending or use the White Label URL to remove SurveyMonkey branding from your web link. If you customize the URL after you send the survey out, both the old link and the new link will work. You can’t create a Custom URL Ending if you have the Recurrence collector option turned on. Tracking Respondents If you want to track respondents, choose the tracking method you want to use before sending your survey. By default, Web link collectors record IP addresses . However, this information can't really help you track respondents. Instead, you can add required questions to your survey to collect identifying information from respondents, or you can use Custom Variables . Or, you can use an Email invitation instead of a Web link to track respondents. Create a Copy of a Web Link Copying a web link creates a new link for you to share a previous survey at a different time or with new respondents. To create a copy of a Web Link collector: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click ... next to the Web link collector you want to copy. Select Copy Collector . A new Web Link starting with Copy of is added to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Most of your customized collector options apply to the copied web link. To review and edit your collector options before sending your survey, select Edit Collector from the survey's three dot dropdown. Copied Collector Options Collector option Copied from original web link Custom Thank You ✅ Survey End Page ✅ Multiple Responses ✅ Response Editing ✅ Anonymous Responses ✅ Instant Results ✅ Response Limits ✅ IP Restrictions ✅ Custom Disqualification ✅ Thumbnail Image and Text ❌ Recurrence ❌ Respondent Authentication ❌ Cutoff Date and Time ❌ Password Protection ❌ Related Articles Language Codes Sending Multilingual Surveys by Email Invitation Matrix Answers Disappear or Deselect Automatically English Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice Copyright © 1999-2025 SurveyMonkey BBB credentials logo TrustedSite logo

Title: Trap Questions | SurveyMonkey Help
Text: Trap Questions | SurveyMonkey Help Log in SurveyMonkey In this article Examples Do I need to add trap questions to my survey? Help Creating Surveys Trap Questions SurveyMonkey Trap Questions Examples Do I need to add trap questions to my survey? Survey creators sometimes add trap questions (or red herring questions) to their surveys to ensure respondents are thoroughly reading the survey questions and not rushing through the survey or satisficing. Adding one or two trap questions allows you to filter out respondents who don't correctly answer the trap question. To do this, filter your survey results by question and answer and only show responses from respondents who chose the correct answer choice. Examples A common trap question is a Multiple Choice question where you ask respondents to select a particular answer choice. Please select B as your answer choice. A B C D E You could also choose to add an incorrect answer choice and filter out respondents who select it. What is your favorite flavor of ice cream? Vanilla Chocolate Strawberry Soccer Mint Chocolate Chip To make your trap question even more difficult to spot, you can add it as a row in a Matrix question. Do I need to add trap questions to my survey? Trap questions are also a common way to identify and control error when purchasing online panels. However, if you're purchasing responses via SurveyMonkey Audience , we feel there is little need for trap questions. We've tested the quality of SurveyMonkey Audience responses by sending the same survey through SurveyMonkey Audience and several other online panel providers. The validity rate for SurveyMonkey Audience was higher in comparison to other panel providers.
